formula.name: enactingText
formula.p: Be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

section.heading: Statement of levelling-up missions

content.p: A Minister of the Crown must prepare, and lay before each House of Parliament, a statement of levelling-up missions.

intro.p: A “statement of levelling-up missions” is a document which sets out—

content.p: objectives which His Majesty’s Government intends to pursue to reduce geographical disparities in the United Kingdom significantly (“levelling-up missions”), within a period specified in the statement (the “mission period”), and
details of how His Majesty’s Government proposes to measure progress in delivering those levelling-up missions (the “mission progress methodology and metrics”).

intro.p: The mission period for a statement of levelling-up missions must not—

content.p: begin before the statement has been laid before each House of Parliament, nor
be shorter than five years.
A statement of levelling-up missions must specify a target date for the delivery of each of the levelling-up missions in it, which may be before or at the end of the mission period.
If different target dates are specified under subsection (4) for different levelling-up missions, the statement of levelling-up missions must give reasons for the different dates.
The first statement of levelling-up missions must come into effect before the end of the period of one month beginning with the day on which this section comes into force.

intro.p: A statement of levelling-up missions comes into effect when—

content.p: the statement has been laid before each House of Parliament and published by a Minister of the Crown, and
the mission period in the statement begins.

Before the end of the mission period in a statement of levelling-up missions (“the old statement”), a Minister of the Crown must prepare a new statement of levelling-up missions, lay it before each House of Parliament and publish it.
The mission period in the new statement of levelling-up missions must begin no later than immediately after the end of the mission period in the old statement.
When the new statement of levelling-up missions comes into effect it replaces the old statement, which ceases to have effect.
References in this Part to the current statement of levelling-up missions are to the statement of levelling-up missions for the time being in effect.

section.heading: Annual etc reports on delivery of levelling-up missions

content.p: A Minister of the Crown must prepare reports on the delivery of the levelling-up missions in the current statement of levelling-up missions, in accordance with this section.

intro.p: Each report must—

content.p: include the Minister’s assessment of the progress that has been made, in the period to which the report relates, in delivering each of the levelling-up missions in the current statement of levelling-up missions as it has effect at the end of that period,
describe what has been done, in that period, by His Majesty’s Government to deliver each of those levelling-up missions, and
set out what His Majesty’s Government plans to do in the future to deliver each of those levelling-up missions.

The Minister’s assessment under subsection (2)(a) must be carried out by reference to the mission progress methodology and metrics in the current statement of levelling-up missions as it has effect at the end of the period to which the report relates.

If His Majesty’s Government considers that it is no longer appropriate for it to pursue a levelling-up mission in the current statement of levelling-up missions, the report may state that His Majesty’s Government no longer intends to pursue that mission, instead of dealing with the matters mentioned in subsection (2) in relation to that mission.
If a report contains a statement under subsection (4), it must also set out the reasons for the statement being made.
The first report in relation to a statement of levelling-up missions must relate to the first 12 months of the mission period in the statement.

intro.p: Subsequent reports in relation to a statement of levelling-up missions must relate to—

content.p: the 12 month period immediately following the 12 month period in relation to which the previous report relating to the statement was prepared, or

intro.p: if shorter, the period—

content.p: beginning immediately after the 12 month period in relation to which the previous report relating to the statement was prepared, and
ending at the end of the mission period in the statement.

section.heading: Reports: Parliamentary scrutiny and publication

content.p: A report under section 2 must be laid before each House of Parliament before the end of the period of 120 days beginning immediately after the last day of the period to which the report relates.
After a report has been laid before Parliament under subsection (1), a Minister of the Crown must publish it as soon as is reasonably practicable.

intro.p: In calculating the period of 120 days mentioned in subsection (1), no account is to be taken of any time during which—

content.p: Parliament is dissolved or prorogued, or
either House of Parliament is adjourned for more than 4 days.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Revision of methodology and metrics or target dates

section.heading: Changes to mission progress methodology and metrics or target dates

content.p: This section applies if a Minister of the Crown considers that the mission progress methodology and metrics, or the target date for the delivery of a levelling-up mission, in the current statement of levelling-up missions should be changed.

intro.p: The Minister—

content.p: may revise the current statement of levelling-up missions so as to change the mission progress methodology and metrics or (as the case may be) target date, and

intro.p: as soon as is reasonably practicable after doing so, must—

content.p: publish a statement setting out the reasons for the mission progress methodology and metrics, or target date, being changed, and
lay the revised statement of levelling-up missions before each House of Parliament and then publish it.
The current statement of levelling-up missions has effect with the revisions made under subsection (2) on and after the day on which it is published after being laid before each House of Parliament.

section.heading: Reviews of statements of levelling-up missions

content.p: A Minister of the Crown must review the current statement of levelling-up missions, in accordance with this section.

The first review of the current statement of levelling-up missions must be completed, and a report on that review published, within the period of five years beginning with the first day of the mission period in that statement.

Subsequent reviews of the current statement of levelling-up missions must be completed, and the report on the review published, within the period of five years beginning with the day on which the report on the previous review was published.

But a final review of the current statement of levelling-up missions must be completed, and the report on the review published, before a new statement is laid before each House of Parliament in accordance with section 1(8).

intro.p: The purposes of a review under this section are to—

content.p: consider whether His Majesty’s Government pursuing the levelling-up missions in the current statement of levelling-up missions is effectively contributing to the reduction of geographical disparities in the United Kingdom,
conclude whether His Majesty’s Government should continue to pursue those levelling-up missions and, if not, what the levelling-up missions are instead to be, and
consider whether there are any additional levelling-up missions which His Majesty’s Government should pursue.
As soon as is reasonably practicable after the conclusion of a review under this section, a Minister of the Crown must lay a report on the review before each House of Parliament and then publish it.

intro.p: The report on a review under this section must—

content.p: state whether His Majesty’s Government considers that pursuing the levelling-up missions in the current statement of levelling-up missions is effectively contributing to the reduction of geographical disparities in the United Kingdom,
state whether His Majesty’s Government has concluded that it should continue to pursue those levelling-up missions and, if not, what the levelling-up missions are instead to be,
state whether there are any additional levelling-up missions which His Majesty’s Government considers it should pursue, and
set out reasons for the statements under paragraphs (a) to (c).
Subsections (9) to (11) do not apply in relation to a report on the final review of the current statement of levelling-up missions.

intro.p: If the report states that His Majesty’s Government has concluded that it should not continue to pursue the levelling-up missions in the current statement of levelling-up missions—
a Minister of the Crown must revise the statement—

content.p: so that it instead contains the levelling-up missions that Her Majesty’s Government is to pursue for the remaining mission period, and
to make any changes to the mission progress methodology and metrics that the Minister considers appropriate in consequence of doing so, and
as soon as is reasonably practicable after revising it, the Minister must lay the revised statement before each House of Parliament and then publish it.

intro.p: If the report states that His Majesty’s Government considers that it should pursue an additional levelling-up mission—
a Minister of the Crown must revise the current statement of levelling-up missions so as to—

content.p: add the levelling-up mission, and
make any changes to the mission progress methodology and metrics that the Minister considers appropriate in consequence of doing so, and
as soon as is reasonably practicable after revising it, the Minister must lay the revised statement before each House of Parliament and then publish it.

The current statement of levelling-up missions has effect with the revisions made under subsection (9)(a) or (10)(a) on and after the day on which the revised statement is published after being laid before each House of Parliament.

section.heading: Interpretation of Part 1

intro.p: In this Part—

content.p: current statement of levelling-up missions has the meaning given by section 1(11);
geographical disparities means geographical disparities in economic, social or other opportunities or outcomes;
levelling-up mission has the meaning given by section 1(2)(a);
Minister of the Crown has the same meaning as in the Ministers of the Crown Act 1975;
mission period has the meaning given by section 1(2)(a);
mission progress methodology and metrics has the meaning given by section 1(2)(b);
statement of levelling-up missions has the meaning given by section 1(2).

section.heading: Combined county authorities and their areas

content.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations establish as a body corporate a combined county authority (a “CCA”) for an area that meets the following conditions.

intro.p: Condition A is that the area is wholly within England and consists of—

content.p: the whole of the area of a two-tier county council, and

intro.p: the whole of one or more of—

content.p: the area of a two-tier county council,
the area of a unitary county council, or
the area of a unitary district council.

intro.p: Condition B is that no part of the area forms part of—

content.p: the area of another CCA,
the area of a combined authority, or
the integrated transport area of an Integrated Transport Authority.
Regulations under subsection (1) must specify the name by which the CCA is to be known.

intro.p: In this Chapter—

content.p: combined authority means a combined authority established under section 103(1) of the Local Democracy, Economic Development and Construction Act 2009;
economic prosperity board means an economic prosperity board established under section 88(1) of that Act;
Integrated Transport Authority means an Integrated Transport Authority for an integrated transport area;
two-tier county council means a county council whose area includes the areas of district councils;
unitary county council means a county council whose area does not include the areas of district councils;
unitary district council means a district council whose area does not form part of the area of a county council.

section.heading: Constitutional arrangements

content.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about the constitutional arrangements of a CCA.

intro.p: “Constitutional arrangements” in relation to a CCA means—

content.p: the membership of the CCA (including the number and appointment of members of the CCA and the remuneration of, and pensions or allowances payable to or in respect of, any member of the CCA);
the voting powers of members of the CCA (including provision for different weight to be given to the vote of different descriptions of member);
the executive arrangements of the CCA;
the functions of any executive body of the CCA.

intro.p: In subsection (2)(c) “executive arrangements” means—

content.p: the appointment of an executive;
the functions of the CCA which are the responsibility of an executive;
the functions of the CCA which are the responsibility of an executive and which may be discharged by a committee of the CCA or by a body other than the CCA;
arrangements relating to the review and scrutiny of the discharge of functions;
access to information on the proceedings of an executive of the CCA;
the disapplication of section 15 of the Local Government and Housing Act 1989 (duty to allocate seats to political groups) in relation to an executive of the CCA or a committee of such an executive;
the keeping of a record of any arrangements relating to the CCA and falling within paragraphs (a) to (f).

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (1) which, by virtue of section (2)(a), include provision about the number and appointment of members of the CCA must provide—
for the members of the CCA other than—

content.p: the mayor (in the case of a mayoral CCA),
the CCA’s non-constituent members (see section 9), and
the CCA’s associate members (see section 10),

wrapUp.p: to be appointed by the CCA’s constituent councils, and

content.p: for each of the constituent councils to appoint at least one of its elected members as a member of the CCA.

intro.p: The provision which may be made by regulations under subsection (1) by virtue of subsection (2)(d) includes—

content.p: provision setting up or dissolving an executive body of a CCA, or merging two or more executive bodies of a CCA;
provision conferring functions on, or removing functions from, an executive body of a CCA;
provision transferring functions of a CCA to an executive body of the CCA, and transferring functions of an executive body of a CCA to the CCA.
Regulations under subsection (1) may not provide for the budget of a CCA to be agreed otherwise than by the CCA.

intro.p: The power to make regulations under subsection (1) is subject to—

content.p: sections 9 and 10 and regulations under section section 11(1) (non-constituent and associate members), and
sections 12(4) and 22(9) and (12) (procedure for CCA consents).

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (1) may be made in relation to a CCA only with the consent of—

content.p: the constituent councils, and
in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA.

intro.p: If the only provision made under subsection (1) in regulations under this Chapter is provision as a result of regulations under section 22(1) (changes to boundaries of a CCA’s area)—

content.p: subsection (8) does not apply to the regulations under this Chapter, and
subsections (6) to (13) of section 22 apply in relation to the regulations as if they contained the provision made by the regulations under subsection (1) of that section.

intro.p: If the only provision made under subsection (1) in regulations under this Chapter is provision as a result of regulations to which section 28 applies (procedure for direct conferral of general functions on mayor)—

content.p: subsection (8) does not apply to the regulations under this Chapter, and
the regulations may be made only with the consent of the mayor for the CCA.

intro.p: In this Chapter “constituent council”, in relation to a CCA or proposed CCA, means—

content.p: a county council for an area within the CCA’s area or proposed area, or
a unitary district council for an area within the CCA’s area or proposed area.

section.heading: Non-constituent members of a CCA

content.p: A CCA may designate a body other than a constituent council as a nominating body for the purposes of this Chapter.
A nominating body may be designated under subsection (1) only if the body consents to the designation.
A nominating body of a CCA may nominate a representative of the body for appointment by the CCA as a member (a “non-constituent member”).
The non-constituent members of a CCA are to be non-voting members of that authority unless the voting members resolve otherwise.
An associate member (see section 10) may not vote on a resolution under subsection (4).
A resolution under subsection (4) does not permit non-constituent members to vote on a decision whether the CCA should consent to the making of regulations under this Chapter.

section.heading: Associate members of a CCA

content.p: A CCA may appoint an individual to be a member (“an associate member”) of the CCA.
The associate members of a CCA are to be non-voting members of the CCA unless the voting members resolve otherwise.
A non-constituent member may not vote on a resolution under subsection (2).
A resolution under subsection (2) does not permit associate members to vote on a decision whether the CCA should consent to the making of regulations under this Chapter.

section.heading: Regulations about members

intro.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about—

content.p: constituent members of a CCA;
the mayor for the area of a CCA in the mayor’s capacity as a member of the CCA;
nominating bodies of a CCA;
non-constituent members of a CCA;
associate members of a CCA.

intro.p: The provision that may be made by regulations under subsection (1) includes, in particular, provision about—

content.p: the cases in which a decision of a CCA requires a majority, or a particular kind of majority, of the votes of members of a particular kind;
the process for the designation of a nominating body or the removal of such a designation;
the number of nominating bodies that may be designated by a CCA;
the number of non-constituent members that may be appointed by a nominating body of a CCA;
the appointment, disqualification, resignation or removal of a non-constituent member;
the appointment of a substitute member to act in place of a non-constituent member;
the maximum number of non-constituent members of a CCA;
the making by a nominating body of a CCA of payments towards the costs of the CCA;
the things which may or may not be done by, or in relation to, a non-constituent member;
the appointment, disqualification, resignation or removal of an associate member;
the appointment of a substitute member to act in place of an associate member;
the maximum number of associate members of a CCA;
the things which may or may not be done by, or in relation to, an associate member.
Regulations under subsection (1) may confer a discretion on a CCA to determine any matter.
In this section “constituent member”, in relation to a CCA, means a member of the CCA (other than any mayor for the area of the CCA) appointed by a constituent council.

section.heading: Review of CCA’s constitutional arrangements

content.p: This section applies if regulations under section 8(1) (constitution of CCA) enable a CCA to make provision about its constitution (“constitutional provision”).

intro.p: An appropriate person may carry out a review of the CCA’s constitutional provision if—

content.p: an appropriate person proposes a review, and
the CCA consents to the review.
If an appropriate person carries out a review under subsection (2), they may propose changes to the CCA’s constitutional provision as a result of the review for agreement by the CCA.

The question of whether to consent under subsection (2)(b) or to agree to changes proposed under subsection (3) is to be decided at a meeting of the CCA by a simple majority of the voting members of the CCA who are present at the meeting.

intro.p: In the case of a mayoral CCA—

content.p: a majority in favour of consenting under subsection (2)(b) does not need to include the mayor, but
a majority in favour of changes proposed under subsection (3) must include the mayor.

intro.p: The reference in subsection (4) to a voting member—

content.p: includes a substitute member who may act in place of a voting member;
does not include a non-constituent or associate member.

intro.p: In this section “appropriate person”, in relation to a CCA, means—

content.p: a member of the CCA appointed by a constituent council, or
the mayor for the area of the CCA, if it is a mayoral CCA (see section 24(8)).

section.heading: Overview and scrutiny committees

content.p: Schedule 1 makes provision for CCAs to have overview and scrutiny committees and audit committees.
Provision made by regulations under section 8(1) is subject to that Schedule.

section.heading: Funding

intro.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision—

content.p: for the costs of a CCA to be met by its constituent councils, and
about the basis on which the amount payable by each constituent council is to be determined.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (1) may be made in relation to a CCA only with the consent of—

content.p: the constituent councils, and
in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA.
Subsection (1) is subject to regulations under section 11(1) (CCA membership).

section.heading: Change of name

content.p: A CCA may, by a resolution in relation to which the requirements mentioned in subsection (2) are met, change the name by which it is known.

intro.p: The requirements are—

content.p: that the resolution is considered at a meeting of the CCA which is specially convened for the purpose,
that particulars of the resolution were included in the notice of the meeting, and
that the resolution is passed at the meeting by not less than two-thirds of the members of the CCA who vote on it.

intro.p: A CCA which changes its name under this section must—

content.p: send notice of the change to the Secretary of State, and
publish the notice in such manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

A change of name under this section does not affect the rights or obligations of the CCA concerned or any other person, or render defective any legal proceedings; and any legal proceedings may be commenced or continued as if there had been no change of name.

section.heading: Local authority functions

content.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for a function of a county council or a district council that is exercisable in relation to an area which is within a CCA’s area to be exercisable by the CCA in relation to the CCA's area.
The Secretary of State may make regulations under subsection (1) only if the Secretary of State considers that the function can appropriately be exercised by the CCA.
Regulations under subsection (1) may make provision for the function to be exercisable by the CCA either generally or subject to such conditions or limitations as may be specified in the regulations.

intro.p: Regulations under this section may make provision—

content.p: for the function to be exercisable by the CCA instead of by the county council or district council,
for the function to be exercisable by the CCA concurrently with the county council or district council,
for the function to be exercisable by the CCA and the county council or district council jointly, or
for the function to be exercisable by the CCA jointly with the county council or district council but also continue to be exercisable by the council alone.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (1) may be made in relation to a CCA only with the consent of—

content.p: the constituent councils, and
in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA

section.heading: Other public authority functions

intro.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations—

content.p: make provision for a function of a public authority that is exercisable in relation to a CCA’s area to be a function of the CCA;
make provision for conferring on a CCA in relation to its area a function corresponding to a function that a public authority has in relation to another area.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (1) may include further provision about the exercise of the function including—

content.p: provision for the function to be exercisable by the public authority or CCA subject to conditions or limitations specified in the regulations;
provision as to joint working arrangements between the CCA and public authority in connection with the function (for example, provision for the function to be exercised by a joint committee).

intro.p: The provision that may be included in regulations under subsection (1)(a) includes, in particular, provision—

content.p: for the CCA to have the function instead of the public authority,
for the function to be exercisable by the CCA concurrently with the public authority,
for the function to be exercisable by the CCA and the public authority jointly, or
for the function to be exercisable by the CCA jointly with the public authority but also continue to be exercisable by the public authority alone.
Regulations under subsection (1)(a) may, in particular, include provision to abolish the public authority in a case where, as a result of the regulations, it will no longer have any functions.

Regulations under subsection (1) may not provide for a regulatory function that is exercisable by a public authority in relation to the whole of England to be exercisable by a CCA in relation to its area if the regulated function is itself exercisable by the CCA by virtue of regulations under this section.

Subsection (7) applies where regulations under subsection (1) contain a reference to a document specified or described in the regulations (for example, in imposing a condition by virtue of subsection (2)(a) for an authority to have regard to, or to comply with, a statement of policy or standards set out in the document).

intro.p: If it appears to the Secretary of State necessary or expedient for the reference to the document to be construed—

content.p: as a reference to that document as amended from time to time, or
as including a reference to a subsequent document that replaces that document,

wrapUp.p: the regulations may make express provision to that effect.

content.p: See also section 18 of the Cities and Local Government Devolution Act 2016 (devolving health service functions) which contains further limitations.

intro.p: In this section—

content.p: function (except in subsection (4)) does not include a power to make regulations or other instruments of a legislative character;
Minister of the Crown has the same meaning as in the Ministers of the Crown Act 1975;

intro.p: public authority—

content.p: includes a Minister of the Crown or a government department;
does not include a county council or a district council;
regulated function means the function of carrying out an activity to which a regulatory function relates;
regulatory function has the meaning given by section 32 of the Legislative and Regulatory Reform Act 2006.

section.heading: Section 17 regulations: procedure

intro.p: The Secretary of State may make regulations under section 17(1) only if—
a proposal for the making of the regulations in relation to the CCA has been made to the Secretary of State—

content.p: as part of a proposal under section 42, or
in accordance with section 44, or

the appropriate consent is given and the Secretary of State considers that the making of the regulations is likely to improve the economic, social and environmental well-being of some or all of the people who live or work in the area or areas to which the regulations relate.

intro.p: For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), the appropriate consent is given to the making of regulations under section 17(1) only if—

content.p: in the case of regulations relating to an existing CCA, each appropriate authority consents;
in any other case, each constituent council consents.

intro.p: The requirements in subsection (1) do not apply where the regulations are made under sections 17(1) and 27(1) in relation to an existing mayoral CCA and provide for a function—

content.p: to be a function of the CCA, and
to be a function exercisable only by the mayor.

wrapUp.p: See section 28 in relation to regulations of this kind.

intro.p: The requirement in subsection (1)(b) for the appropriate consent to be given to the making of regulations under section 17(1) does not apply where—

content.p: the regulations revoke (in whole or in part), or otherwise amend, previous regulations under section 17(1), and
the only purpose of the regulations is to provide for a health service function of a CCA to cease to be exercisable by the CCA.

intro.p: In subsection (4)(b) “health service function of a CCA” means a function which—

content.p: relates to the health service, as defined by section 275(1) of the National Health Service Act 2006, and
is exercisable by the CCA by virtue of regulations under section 17(1).

At the same time as laying a draft of a statutory instrument containing regulations under section 17(1) before Parliament, the Secretary of State must lay before Parliament a report explaining the effect of the regulations and why the Secretary of State considers it appropriate to make the regulations.

intro.p: The report must include—

content.p: a description of any consultation taken into account by the Secretary of State,
information about any representations considered by the Secretary of State in connection with the regulations, and
any other evidence or contextual information that the Secretary of State considers it appropriate to include.

intro.p: For the purposes of this section “the appropriate authorities” are—

content.p: each constituent council, and
in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA.

section.heading: Integrated Transport Authority and Passenger Transport Executive

content.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations transfer functions of an Integrated Transport Authority (an “ITA”) to a CCA.

Regulations under subsection (1) may only be made in relation to functions exercisable by the ITA in relation to an area that becomes, or becomes part of, the CCA’s area by virtue of regulations under this Chapter.

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for any function that is conferred or imposed on a Passenger Transport Executive by any enactment (whenever passed or made) to be exercisable by a CCA or the executive body of a CCA in relation to the CCA’s area.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (3) may make provision for any function that—

content.p: is conferred or imposed on an ITA by any enactment (whenever passed or made), and
relates to the functions of a Passenger Transport Executive,

wrapUp.p: to be exercisable by a CCA in relation to the CCA’s area.

intro.p: Regulations under this section may be made in relation to a CCA only with the consent of—

content.p: the constituent councils, and
in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA.

section.heading: Directions relating to highways and traffic functions

content.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations confer on a CCA a power to give a direction about the exercise of an eligible power.

intro.p: An “eligible power” means a power of a county council or a unitary district council which the council has—

content.p: as highway authority by virtue of section 1 of the Highways Act 1980, or
as traffic authority by virtue of section 121A of the Road Traffic Regulation Act 1984.
In this section references to a power do not include a reference to a duty.

intro.p: A power of direction under this section must relate only to the exercise of an eligible power in—

content.p: the area of the CCA, and
the area of the authority subject to the direction.

intro.p: A power of direction under this section must relate only to the exercise of an eligible power in respect of—

content.p: a particular road (whether or not specified in the regulations), or
a description of road (whether or not specified in the regulations).

intro.p: In subsection (5) “road”—

content.p: has the meaning given by section 142(1) of the Road Traffic Regulation Act 1984, and
does not include any road which is the subject of a concession agreement under Part 1 of the New Roads and Street Works Act 1991.

intro.p: A power of direction under this section must relate only to any one or more of—

content.p: the provision of information about the exercise of an eligible power which the authority subject to the direction has or might reasonably be expected to acquire;
the imposition on such an authority of requirements relating to procedures to be followed prior to the exercise of an eligible power;
the imposition on such an authority of requirements relating to the obtaining of consent prior to the exercise of an eligible power;

the imposition on such an authority of conditions subject to which an eligible power may be exercised (including conditions relating to the times at which, and the manner in which, an eligible power may be exercised);
a requirement to exercise an eligible power (including a requirement to exercise an eligible power subject to conditions);
a prohibition on the exercise of an eligible power.
A power of direction under this section may be conferred subject to conditions.

intro.p: Any direction given by virtue of this section—

content.p: must be given in writing and may be varied or revoked by a further direction in writing, and
may make different provision for different cases and different provision for different areas.

If regulations under subsection (1) make provision for a direction by virtue of subsection (7)(e), the regulations must make provision for the direction not to have effect unless the CCA meets the cost of complying with the direction.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (1) may be made in relation to a CCA only with the consent of—

content.p: the constituent councils, and
in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA.

section.heading: Contravention of regulations under section 20

content.p: Regulations under section 20(1) may provide that, if an authority exercises any power in contravention of a direction under such regulations, the CCA may take such steps as it considers appropriate to reverse or modify the effect of the exercise of the power.
For the purposes of subsection (1), the CCA has power to exercise any power of the authority subject to the direction on behalf of that authority.
Any reasonable expenses incurred by the CCA in taking any steps under subsection (1) are recoverable from the authority subject to the direction as a civil debt.

section.heading: Changes to boundaries of a CCA’s area

intro.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations change the boundaries of a CCA’s area by—

content.p: adding a relevant local government area to an existing area of a CCA, or
removing a relevant local government area from an existing area of a CCA.

intro.p: In this section “relevant local government area” means—

content.p: the area of a two-tier county council,
the area of a unitary county council, or
the area of a unitary district council.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (1)(b)—

content.p: may transfer functions relating to the relevant local government area from the CCA to any other public authority;
may provide for any function of the CCA relating to the area to be no longer exercisable in relation to that area.

intro.p: In subsection (3)(a) “public authority” includes—

content.p: a Minister of the Crown within the meaning of the Ministers of the Crown Act 1975,
a government department,
a county council, and
a district council.
Regulations may be made under subsection (1) only if the area to be created by the regulations meets conditions A and B in section 7.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (1) adding or removing a relevant local government area to or from an existing area of a mayoral CCA may be made only if—

content.p: the relevant council in relation to the relevant local government area consents, and
the mayor for the area of the CCA consents.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (1) adding or removing a relevant local government area to or from an existing area of a CCA which is not a mayoral CCA may be made only if—

content.p: the relevant council in relation to the relevant local government area consents, and
the CCA consents.

intro.p: For the purposes of subsections (6)(a) and (7)(a), the “relevant council” in relation to a relevant local government area is—

content.p: if the local government area is the area of a county council, the county council;
if the local government area is the area of a unitary district council, the unitary district council.

The question of whether to consent under subsection (7)(b) to regulations under subsection (1) is to be decided at a meeting of the CCA by a simple majority of the voting members of the authority who are present at the meeting.

intro.p: Where regulations under subsection (1)(b) are made as a result of the duty in section 25(3)—

content.p: subsection (5) does not apply, and
neither subsection (6) nor subsection (7) applies.
Subsection (12) applies if a CCA has made provision about its constitution under regulations under section 8(1).

A decision about any change to that provision as a result of regulations under subsection (1) is to be decided at a meeting of the CCA by a simple majority of the voting members of the CCA who are present at the meeting.

intro.p: A reference in this section to a voting member—

content.p: includes a substitute member who may act in place of a voting member;
does not include a non-constituent or associate member.

section.heading: Dissolution of a CCA’s area

intro.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations—

content.p: dissolve a CCA’s area, and
abolish the CCA for that area.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (1)—

content.p: may transfer functions from the CCA to any other public authority;
may provide for any function of the CCA to be no longer exercisable in relation to the CCA’s area.

intro.p: In subsection (2)(a) “public authority” includes—

content.p: a Minister of the Crown within the meaning of the Ministers of the Crown Act 1975,
a government department,
a county council, and
a district council.

intro.p: Regulations may be made under subsection (1) only if—

content.p: a majority of the constituent councils consent to the making of the regulations, and
in the case of regulations made in relation to a mayoral CCA, the mayor for the area of the CCA also consents to the making of the regulations.

section.heading: Power to provide for election of mayor

content.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for there to be a mayor for the area of a CCA.
A mayor for the area of a CCA is to be elected by the local government electors for that area in accordance with provision made by or under this Chapter.
In subsection (2) “local government elector” has the meaning given by section 270(1) of the Local Government Act 1972.
Schedule 2 makes further provision about the election of mayors for areas of CCAs.
A mayor for the area of a CCA is entitled to the style of “mayor”.
A mayor for the area of a CCA is by virtue of that office a member of, and the chair of, the CCA.

Regulations under subsection (1) providing for there to be a mayor for the area of a CCA may not be revoked by making further regulations under subsection (1); but this does not prevent the making of regulations under section 23(1) abolishing the CCA (together with the office of mayor).
In this Chapter “mayoral CCA” means a CCA for an area for which provision is made in regulations under subsection (1) for there to be a mayor.

section.heading: Requirements in connection with regulations under section 24

intro.p: The Secretary of State may make regulations under section 24(1) in relation to a CCA's area if a proposal for there to be a mayor for the CCA's area has been made to the Secretary of State—

content.p: as part of a proposal under section 42, or
in accordance with section 44.

intro.p: Regulations under section 24(1) may also be made without any such proposal having been made if—

content.p: the appropriate authorities consent, or
in the case of an existing CCA, there are one or more non-consenting constituent councils but the CCA and at least two constituent councils consent.

Where regulations under section 24(1) are made by virtue of subsection (2)(b) of this section, the Secretary of State must make regulations under section 22(1)(b) to remove the area of each non-consenting constituent council from the existing area of the CCA.

intro.p: For the purposes of this section “the appropriate authorities” are—

content.p: the constituent councils, and
in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA.

section.heading: Deputy mayors etc

content.p: The mayor for the area of a CCA must appoint one of the members of the authority to be the mayor's deputy.
The deputy mayor holds office until the end of the term of office of the mayor, subject to subsection (3).

intro.p: A person ceases to be the deputy mayor if at any time—

content.p: the mayor removes the person from office,
the person resigns as deputy mayor, or
the person ceases to be a member of the CCA.
If a vacancy occurs in the office of deputy mayor, the mayor must appoint another member of the CCA to be deputy mayor.

intro.p: The deputy mayor must act in place of the mayor if for any reason—

content.p: the mayor is unable to act, or
the office of mayor is vacant.

intro.p: If for any reason—

content.p: the mayor is unable to act or the office of mayor is vacant, and
the deputy mayor is unable to act or the office of deputy mayor is vacant,

wrapUp.p: the other members of the CCA must act together in place of the mayor, taking decisions by a simple majority.

content.p: In this Chapter “deputy mayor”, in relation to a mayoral CCA, means the person appointed under this section by the mayor for the authority's area.
References in this section to a member of a CCA do not include a non-constituent or associate member.

section.heading: Functions of mayors: general

content.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for any function of a mayoral CCA to be a function exercisable only by the mayor.
In this Chapter references to “general functions”, in relation to a mayor for the area of a CCA, are to any functions exercisable by the mayor other than PCC functions (see section 30(3)).

intro.p: The mayor may arrange—

content.p: for the deputy mayor to exercise any general function of the mayor,
for another member or officer of the CCA to exercise any such function,

intro.p: so far as authorised by regulations made by the Secretary of State—

content.p: for a person appointed as the deputy mayor for policing and crime by virtue of regulations under paragraph 3(1) of Schedule 3, or
for a committee of the CCA, consisting of members appointed by the mayor (whether or not members of the CCA),
The reference in subsection (3)(b) to a member of a CCA does not include a non-constituent or associate member.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (3)(c)(ii) may include provision—

content.p: about the membership of the committee;
about the member of the committee who is to be its chair;
about the appointment of members;
about the voting powers of members (including provision for different weight to be given to the vote of different descriptions of member);
about information held by the CCA that must, or must not, be disclosed to the committee for purposes connected to the exercise of the committee's functions;
applying (with or without modifications) sections 15 to 17 of, and Schedule 1 to, the Local Government and Housing Act 1989 (political balance on local authority committees etc).
Regulations under subsection (3)(c) must provide that the committee must not consist solely of non-constituent or associate members.

intro.p: Provision in regulations under subsection (1) for a function to be exercisable only by the mayor is subject to subsection (3); but the Secretary of State may by regulations provide that arrangements under subsection (3)—

content.p: may authorise the exercise of general functions only of a description specified in the regulations, or
may not authorise the exercise of general functions of a description so specified.

intro.p: Any general function exercisable by the mayor for the area of a CCA by virtue of this Act is to be taken to be a function of the CCA exercisable—

content.p: by the mayor individually, or
in accordance with arrangements made by virtue of this section or section 29 or 31.

intro.p: Regulations under this section may—

content.p: include provision for general functions to be exercisable by the mayor subject to conditions or limitations specified in the regulations (including, for example, a condition for general functions to be exercisable only with the consent of the appropriate authorities (as defined by section 25(4)));
provide for members or officers of a mayoral CCA to assist the mayor in the exercise of general functions;
confer ancillary powers on the mayor for the purposes of the exercise of general functions;
authorise the mayor to appoint one person as the mayor's political adviser;
provide for the terms and conditions of any such appointment;

provide that functions that the mayoral CCA discharges in accordance with arrangements under section 101(1)(b) of the Local Government Act 1972 (discharge of local authority functions by another authority) are to be treated as general functions exercisable by the mayor (so far as authorised by the arrangements).

intro.p: Provision under subsection (9)(c) may include provision conferring power on the mayor that is similar to any power exercisable by the mayoral CCA—

content.p: under section 46 (general power of CCA), or
under regulations made under section 49(1) (general power of competence),

wrapUp.p: but the power conferred on the mayor may not include a power to borrow money.

intro.p: Regulations under this section may be made only with the consent of—

content.p: the appropriate authorities (as defined by section 25(4)), and
in the case of regulations made in relation to an existing mayoral CCA, the mayor of the CCA.

Where regulations under this section are contained in the same instrument as regulations made by virtue of section 25(2)(b), a non-consenting constituent council is not to be treated as an appropriate authority for the purposes of subsection (11).

intro.p: The requirement in subsection (11) does not apply where the regulations are made under section 17(1) and subsection (1) of this section in relation to an existing mayoral CCA and provide for a function—

content.p: to be a function of the CCA, and
to be a function exercisable only by the mayor.

wrapUp.p: See section 28 in relation to regulations of this kind.

section.heading: Procedure for direct conferral of general functions on mayor

intro.p: This section applies in relation to regulations which are made under sections 17(1) and 27(1) in relation to an existing mayoral CCA and provide for a function—

content.p: to be a function of the CCA, and
to be a function exercisable only by the mayor.
The Secretary of State may make the regulations only if a request for the making of the regulations has been made to the Secretary of State by the mayor.
Before submitting a request under this section, the mayor must consult the constituent councils.

intro.p: A request under this section must contain—

content.p: a statement by the mayor that all of the constituent councils agree to the making of the regulations, or
if the mayor is unable to make that statement, the reasons why the mayor considers the regulations should be made even though not all of the constituent councils agree to them being made.

section.heading: Joint exercise of general functions

content.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for, or in connection with, permitting arrangements under section 101(5) of the Local Government Act 1972 to be entered into in relation to general functions of a mayor for the area of a CCA.

intro.p: Provision under subsection (1) may include provision—

content.p: for the mayor for the area of a CCA to be a party to the arrangements in place of, or jointly with, the CCA;
about the membership of any joint committee;
about the member of the joint committee who is to be its chair;
about the appointment of members to a joint committee;
about the voting powers of members of a joint committee (including provision for different weight to be given to the vote of different descriptions of member).

intro.p: Provision under subsection (2)(b) to (d) may include provision for the mayor or other persons—

content.p: to determine the number of members;
to have the power to appoint members (whether or not members of the CCA or a local authority that is a party to the arrangements).

Provision under subsection (2)(d) may include provision as to the circumstances in which appointments to a joint committee need not be made in accordance with sections 15 to 17 of, and Schedule 1 to, the Local Government and Housing Act 1989 (political balance on local authority committees etc).

In this section references to a joint committee are to a joint committee falling within section 101(5)(a) of the Local Government Act 1972 that is authorised to discharge, by virtue of regulations under this section, general functions of a mayor for the area of a CCA.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Police and crime and fire and rescue functions

section.heading: Functions of mayors: policing

content.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for the mayor for the area of a CCA to exercise functions of a police and crime commissioner in relation to that area.

intro.p: The reference in subsection (1) to functions of a police and crime commissioner is to any functions conferred on police and crime commissioners by or under—

content.p: Part 1 of the Police Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011, or
any other Act (whenever passed).

In this Chapter references to “PCC functions”, in relation to a mayor for the area of a CCA, are to the functions of a police and crime commissioner that are exercisable by the mayor by virtue of subsection (1).
Regulations under subsection (1) may be made in relation to an existing mayoral CCA only with the consent of the mayor of the CCA.

intro.p: If regulations are made under subsection (1) in relation to a CCA’s area—

content.p: the Secretary of State must by regulations provide that there is to be no police and crime commissioner for that area as from a specified date;

the Secretary of State may by regulations provide that any election of a police and crime commissioner for that area that would otherwise take place (whether before or after the specified date) by virtue of section 50(1)(b) of the Police Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011 is not to take place.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (5) may include provision—

content.p: for the term of office of a police and crime commissioner to continue until the date specified in regulations under subsection (5)(a) (in spite of section 50(7)(b) of the Police Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011);

for an election to fill a vacancy in the office of a police and crime commissioner, which otherwise would take place under section 51 of that Act, not to take place if the vacancy occurs within a period of six months ending with the specified date.
Schedule 3 contains further provision in connection with regulations under this section.

intro.p: Any PCC function exercisable by the mayor for the area of a CCA by virtue of this Act is to be taken to be a function of the CCA exercisable—

content.p: by the mayor acting individually, or.
by a person acting under arrangements with the mayor made in accordance with provision made under Schedule 3.

section.heading: Exercise of fire and rescue functions

intro.p: This section applies to a mayor for the area of a CCA who—

content.p: by virtue of section 27(1), may exercise functions which are conferred on a fire and rescue authority in that name (“fire and rescue functions”), and
by virtue of section 30(1), may exercise functions of a police and crime commissioner.

intro.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision—

content.p: authorising the mayor to arrange for the chief constable of the police force for the police area which corresponds to the area of the CCA to exercise fire and rescue functions exercisable by the mayor;
authorising that chief constable to arrange for a person within subsection (4) to exercise the chief constable's fire and rescue functions.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (2) may provide that arrangements made under the regulations—

content.p: may authorise the exercise of any functions mentioned in that subsection;
may authorise the exercise of any functions mentioned in that subsection other than those specified or described in the regulations;
may authorise the exercise of such of the functions mentioned in that subsection as are specified or described in the regulations.

intro.p: The persons mentioned in subsection (2)(b) are—

content.p: members of the chief constable's police force;
the civilian staff of that police force, as defined by section 102(4) of the Police Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011;
members of staff transferred to the chief constable under a scheme made by virtue of section 33(1);
members of staff appointed by the chief constable under section 33(2).
Provision in regulations under section 27(1) for a function to be exercisable only by the mayor for the area of a CCA is subject to provision made by virtue of subsection (2).

intro.p: This section is subject to—

content.p: section 32 (section 31 regulations: procedure), and
section 37 of the Fire and Rescue Services Act 2004 (prohibition on employment of police in fire-fighting).

intro.p: In this section “fire and rescue functions”, in relation to a chief constable, means—

content.p: functions which are exercisable by the chief constable by virtue of provision made under subsection (2)(a), and
functions relating to fire and rescue services which are conferred on the chief constable by or by virtue of any enactment.

section.heading: Section 31 regulations: procedure

content.p: Regulations under section 31(2) may be made in relation to the mayor for the area of a CCA only if the mayor has requested the Secretary of State to make the regulations.

intro.p: A request under subsection (1) must be accompanied by a report which contains—
an assessment of why—

content.p: it is in the interests of economy, efficiency and effectiveness for the regulations to be made, or
it is in the interests of public safety for the regulations to be made,
a description of any public consultation which the mayor has carried out on the proposal for the regulations to be made,
a summary of the responses to any such consultation, and
a summary of the representations (if any) which the mayor has received about that proposal from the constituent members of the CCA.

Before making the request the mayor must publish, in such manner as the mayor thinks appropriate, the mayor's response to the representations made or views expressed in response to any consultations on the proposal.

intro.p: Subsections (5) to (7) apply if—

content.p: the mayor for the area of a CCA makes a request under subsection (1) for the Secretary of State to make regulations under section 31(2), and
at least two thirds of the constituent members of the CCA have indicated that they disagree with the proposal for the regulations to be made.

intro.p: The mayor must, in providing the report under subsection (2), provide the Secretary of State with—

content.p: copies of the representations (if any) made by the constituent members of the CCA about that proposal, and
the mayor's response to those representations and to the responses to any public consultation which the mayor has carried out on that proposal.

intro.p: The Secretary of State must—

content.p: obtain an independent assessment of that proposal, and
in deciding whether to make the regulations, have regard to that assessment and to the material provided under subsection (5) (as well as the material provided under subsection (2)).

intro.p: The Secretary of State must publish the independent assessment—

content.p: as soon as is reasonably practicable after making a determination in response to the proposal, and
in such manner as the Secretary of State thinks appropriate.

intro.p: Regulations under section 31(2) may be made only if it appears to the Secretary of State that—

content.p: it is in the interests of economy, efficiency and effectiveness for the regulations to be made, or
it is in the interests of public safety for the regulations to be made.

The Secretary of State may not make regulations under section 31(2) in a case within subsection (8)(a) of this section if the Secretary of State thinks that the regulations would have an adverse effect on public safety.

The Secretary of State may, in making regulations under section 31(2) in relation to the mayor for the area of a CCA, give effect to the mayor's proposal for the regulations with such modifications as the Secretary of State thinks appropriate.
Before making regulations which give effect to such a proposal with modifications, the Secretary of State must consult the mayor and the CCA on the modifications.
In this section “constituent member”, in relation to a CCA, means a member of the CCA appointed by a constituent council (but does not include the mayor for the area of the CCA).

section.heading: Section 31 regulations: further provision

intro.p: Regulations under section 31(2) may make provision for the making of a scheme to transfer property, rights and liabilities (including criminal liabilities)—

content.p: from a fire and rescue authority or the CCA to the chief constable, or
from the chief constable to the CCA,

wrapUp.p: (including provision corresponding to any provision made by section 17(4) to (6) of the Localism Act 2011).

content.p: A chief constable to whom regulations under section 31(2) apply may appoint staff for the purpose of the exercise of the chief constable's fire and rescue functions.

intro.p: A chief constable to whom regulations under section 31(2) apply may—

content.p: pay remuneration, allowances and gratuities to members of the chief constable's fire and rescue staff;
pay pensions to, or in respect of, persons who are or have been such members of staff;
pay amounts for or towards the provision of pensions to, or in respect of, persons who are or have been such members of staff.
In subsection (3) “allowances”, in relation to a member of staff, means allowances in respect of expenses incurred by the member of staff in the course of employment as such a member of staff.

Subject to subsections (6) to (8), a person who is employed pursuant to a transfer by virtue of subsection (1) or an appointment under subsection (2) may not at the same time be employed pursuant to an appointment by a chief constable of the police force for a police area under Schedule 2 to the Police Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011.

Where regulations under section 31(2) are in force in relation to the chief constable of the police force for a police area, the person who is for the time being the police force's chief finance officer is to be responsible for the proper administration of financial affairs relating to the exercise of the chief constable's fire and rescue functions.
Subsection (5) does not prevent a person who is employed as a finance officer for fire functions from being at the same time employed as a finance officer for police functions.

intro.p: In subsection (7)—
finance officer for fire functions means a member of a chief constable's fire and rescue staff who—

content.p: is not a chief finance officer of the kind mentioned in subsection (6), and
is employed to carry out duties relating to the proper administration of financial affairs relating to the exercise of the chief constable's fire and rescue functions;

intro.p: finance officer for police functions means a member of a chief constable's civilian staff within the meaning of the Police Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011 who—

content.p: is not a chief finance officer of the kind mentioned in subsection (6), and
is employed to carry out duties relating to the proper administration of a police force's financial affairs.

intro.p: Where regulations under section 31(2) are in force, the CCA to which the regulations apply must pay—

content.p: any damages or costs awarded against the chief constable to whom the regulations apply in any proceedings brought against the chief constable in respect of the acts or omissions of a member of the chief constable's fire and rescue staff;
any costs incurred by the chief constable in any such proceedings so far as not recovered by the chief constable in the proceedings;

any sum required in connection with the settlement of any claim made against the chief constable in respect of the acts or omissions of a member of the chief constable's fire and rescue staff, if the settlement is approved by the CCA.

intro.p: Where regulations under section 31(2) are in force, the CCA to which the regulations apply may, in such cases and to such extent as appears to the CCA to be appropriate, pay—

content.p: any damages or costs awarded against a member of the fire and rescue staff of the chief constable to whom the regulations apply in proceedings for any unlawful conduct of that member of staff;
costs incurred and not recovered by such a member of staff in such proceedings;
sums required in connection with the settlement of a claim that has or might have given rise to such proceedings.

intro.p: In this section—

content.p: fire and rescue functions has the same meaning as in section 31;

intro.p: fire and rescue staff, in relation to a chief constable to whom regulations under section 31(2) apply, means—

content.p: staff transferred to the chief constable under a scheme made by virtue of subsection (1);
staff appointed by the chief constable under subsection (2).

section.heading: Section 31 regulations: exercise of fire and rescue functions

intro.p: This section applies if—

content.p: regulations under section 31(2) make provision in relation to the area of a CCA, and

by virtue of the regulations, fire and rescue functions exercisable by the mayor for the area of the CCA are exercisable by the chief constable of the police force for the police area which corresponds to that area.

intro.p: The chief constable must secure that good value for money is obtained in exercising—

content.p: functions which are exercisable by the chief constable by virtue of the regulations, and
functions relating to fire and rescue services which are conferred on the chief constable by or by virtue of any enactment.
The chief constable must secure that other persons exercising functions by virtue of the regulations obtain good value for money in exercising those functions.

intro.p: The mayor must—

content.p: secure the exercise of the duties which are exercisable by the chief constable or another person by virtue of the regulations,
secure the exercise of the duties relating to fire and rescue services which are imposed on the chief constable by or by virtue of any enactment,
secure that functions which are exercisable by the chief constable or another person by virtue of the regulations are exercised efficiently and effectively, and
secure that functions relating to fire and rescue services which are conferred or imposed on the chief constable by or by virtue of any enactment are exercised efficiently and effectively.
The mayor must hold the chief constable to account for the exercise of such functions.

section.heading: Section 31 regulations: complaints and conduct matters etc

content.p: If regulations are made under section 31(2) that enable arrangements to be made for the exercise of functions by members of a police force or the civilian staff of a police force, the Secretary of State may by regulations amend Part 2 of the Police Reform Act 2002 (persons serving with the police: complaints and conduct matters etc) in consequence of that provision.

If regulations are made under section 31(2) that enable arrangements to be made for the exercise of functions by members of staff transferred to a chief constable under a scheme made by virtue of section 33(1) or appointed by a chief constable under section 33(2), the Secretary of State may by regulations make provision of the type described in subsection (3) in relation to those members of staff.

intro.p: The provision referred to in subsection (2) is—

content.p: provision corresponding or similar to any provision made by or under Part 2 of the Police Reform Act 2002;
provision applying (with or without modifications) any provision made by or under Part 2 of that Act.
The Secretary of State may by regulations, in consequence of any provision made under subsection (2), amend Part 2 of the Police Reform Act 2002.

intro.p: Before making regulations under this section the Secretary of State must consult—

content.p: the Police Advisory Board for England and Wales,
the Director General of the Independent Office for Police Conduct,
such persons as appear to the Secretary of State to represent the views of police and crime commissioners,
such persons as appear to the Secretary of State to represent the views of fire and rescue authorities, and
such other persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

section.heading: Section 31 regulations: application of fire and rescue provisions

intro.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations—

content.p: apply (with or without modifications) any provision of a fire and rescue enactment in relation to a person within subsection (2);
make, in relation to a person within subsection (2), provision corresponding or similar to any provision of a fire and rescue enactment.

intro.p: Those persons are—

content.p: a chief constable of a police force for a police area to whom regulations under section 31(2) apply,
a member of staff transferred to such a chief constable under a scheme made by virtue of section 33(1),
a member of staff appointed by such a chief constable under section 33(2),
a member of such a chief constable's police force by whom functions are exercisable by virtue of section 31(2)(b), and

a member of the civilian staff of such a police force (as defined by section 102(4) of the Police Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011) by whom functions are exercisable by virtue of section 31(2)(b).

The power conferred by subsection (1)(a) or (b) includes power to apply (with or without modifications) any provision made under a fire and rescue enactment or make provision corresponding or similar to any such provision.
The Secretary of State may by regulations amend, revoke or repeal a provision of or made under an enactment in consequence of provision made by virtue of subsection (1).

In this section “fire and rescue enactment” means an enactment relating to a fire and rescue authority (including, in particular, an enactment relating to an employee of such an authority or property of such an authority).

References in this section to an enactment or to provision made under an enactment are to an enactment whenever passed or (as the case may be) to provision whenever the instrument containing it is made.

section.heading: Section 31 regulations: application of local policing provisions

intro.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations—

content.p: apply (with or without modifications) any provision of a local policing enactment in relation to a person within subsection (2);
make, in relation to such a person, provision corresponding or similar to any provision of a local policing enactment.

intro.p: Those persons are—

content.p: a mayor for the area of a CCA to whom regulations under section 31(2) apply,
a chief constable to whom such regulations apply, and
a panel established by virtue of regulations under paragraph 4 of Schedule 3 for such an area.

The power conferred by subsection (1)(a) or (b) includes power to apply (with or without modifications) any provision made under a local policing enactment or make provision corresponding or similar to any such provision.
The Secretary of State may by regulations amend, revoke or repeal a provision of or made under an enactment in consequence of provision made by virtue of subsection (1).
In this section “local policing enactment” means an enactment relating to a police and crime commissioner.

References in this section to an enactment or to provision made under an enactment are to an enactment whenever passed or (as the case may be) to provision whenever the instrument containing it is made.

section.heading: Mayors for CCA areas: financial matters

content.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for the costs of a mayor for the area of a CCA that are incurred in, or in connection with, the exercise of mayoral functions to be met from precepts issued by the CCA under section 40 of the Local Government Finance Act 1992.

The function of issuing precepts under Chapter 4 of Part 1 of the Local Government Finance Act 1992 in respect of mayoral functions is to be a function exercisable only by the mayor acting on behalf of the CCA.

The Secretary of State may by regulations modify the application of Chapter 4 or 4ZA of Part 1 of the Local Government Finance Act 1992 so far as applying to cases where the precepting authority in question under that Chapter is a mayoral CCA.

intro.p: Where the mayoral functions of a mayor include PCC functions—

content.p: the provision made by virtue of subsection (3) must include provision to ensure that the council tax requirement calculated under section 42A of the Local Government Finance Act 1992 consists of separate components in respect of the mayor's PCC functions and the mayor's general functions, and
the function of calculating the component in respect of the mayor's PCC functions is itself to be treated as a PCC function for the purposes of this Part.

intro.p: The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision—

content.p: requiring the mayor to maintain a fund in relation to receipts arising, and liabilities incurred, in the exercise of general functions;
about the preparation of an annual budget in relation to the exercise of general functions.

wrapUp.p: (For power to make corresponding provision in relation to PCC functions, see paragraph 7 of Schedule 3.)

intro.p: Provision under subsection (5)(b) may in particular include provision for—

content.p: the mayor to prepare a draft budget;

intro.p: the draft to be scrutinised by—

content.p: the other members of the CCA, and
a committee of the CCA appointed in accordance with paragraph 1(1) of Schedule 1;
the making of changes to the draft as a result of such scrutiny;
the approval of the draft by the CCA (including a power to veto the draft in circumstances specified in the regulations and the consequences of any such veto);
the basis on which such approval is to be given.
The reference in subsection (6)(b)(i) to a member of a CCA does not include a non-constituent or associate member.

intro.p: In this section “mayoral functions”, in relation to a mayor, means—

content.p: the mayor's general functions, and
if the mayor exercises PCC functions, the mayor's PCC functions.

section.heading: Alternative mayoral titles

intro.p: At the first meeting of a mayoral CCA after regulations made under section 24(1) come into force, the CCA must, by a resolution in accordance with subsection (3)—

content.p: provide that the mayor for the area of the CCA is to be known by the title of mayor, or
change the title by which the mayor for the area of the CCA is to be known to an alternative title mentioned in subsection (2).

intro.p: The alternative titles are—

content.p: county commissioner;
county governor;
elected leader;
governor;
a title that the CCA considers more appropriate than the alternative titles mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d), having regard to the title of other public office holders in the area of the CCA.

intro.p: The following requirements must be met in relation to the resolution mentioned in subsection (1)—

content.p: particulars of the resolution must be included in the notice of the meeting,

where the resolution includes a proposed alternative title mentioned in subsection (2)(e), the resolution must specify why the CCA considers that the title is more appropriate than the other alternative titles mentioned in subsection (2), and
the resolution must be passed at the meeting by a simple majority of the members of the CCA who vote on it.
Subsections (5) and (6) apply where under this section a mayoral CCA changes the title by which the mayor for the area of the CCA is to be known to an alternative title.

intro.p: The CCA must—

content.p: send notice of the change to the Secretary of State,
publish the notice in the area of the CCA in such manner as the CCA considers appropriate, and
publish the notice in such other manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

intro.p: Where this subsection applies—

content.p: a reference in any enactment (whenever passed or made) to the mayor for the area of the CCA is, unless the context otherwise requires, to be read as a reference to the alternative title by which the mayor is to be known, and
references to mayor, mayoral (except in the expression “mayoral CCA”) and deputy mayor are to be construed accordingly.

A change of title under this section does not affect the rights or obligations of any person or render defective any legal proceedings; and any legal proceedings may be commenced or continued as if there had been no change of title.
In this section a reference to a member of a CCA does not include a non-constituent member or an associate member.

intro.p: In this section “enactment”—

content.p: includes an enactment comprised in subordinate legislation within the meaning of the Interpretation Act 1978, but
does not include this section or section 40.

section.heading: Alternative mayoral titles: further changes

intro.p: This section applies where a mayoral CCA has—

content.p: by a resolution under section 39 or by a previous resolution under this section, changed the title by which the mayor for the area of the CCA is to be known to an alternative title,
by a resolution under section 39, provided that the mayor for the area of the CCA is to be known by the title of mayor, or
by a previous resolution under this section, provided that the mayor for the area of the CCA is no longer to be known by an alternative title.

intro.p: The CCA may, by a resolution in accordance with this section—
in a subsection (1)(a) case—

content.p: provide that the mayor is no longer to be known by the alternative title, or
change the title by which the mayor is to be known to an alternative title mentioned in subsection (3);
in a subsection (1)(b) or (c) case, change the title by which the mayor is to be known to an alternative title mentioned in subsection (3).

intro.p: The alternative titles mentioned in subsection (2) are as follows—

content.p: county commissioner;
county governor;
elected leader;
governor;
a title that the CCA considers more appropriate than the alternative titles mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d), having regard to the title of other public office holders in the area of the CCA.

intro.p: The following requirements must be met in relation to the resolution mentioned in subsection (2)—

content.p: the resolution must be considered at a relevant meeting of the CCA,
particulars of the resolution must be included in the notice of the meeting,

where the resolution includes a proposed alternative title mentioned in subsection (3)(e), the resolution must specify why the CCA considers that the title is more appropriate than the other alternative titles mentioned in subsection (3), and
the resolution must be passed at the meeting by a simple majority of the members of the CCA who vote on it.

In subsection (4)(a) “relevant meeting” means the first meeting of the CCA held after a qualifying election for the return of the mayor, provided that the election is at least the third qualifying election since the resolution mentioned in subsection (1) was passed.

intro.p: Where under this section an authority provides that the mayor for the area of the CCA is no longer to be known by an alternative title, the CCA must—

content.p: send notice of the change to the Secretary of State, and
publish the notice in the area of the CCA in such manner as the CCA considers appropriate, and
publish the notice in such other manner as the Secretary of State may direct.
Subsections (8) and (9) apply where under this section a CCA changes the title by which the mayor for the area of the CCA is to be known to an alternative title.

intro.p: The authority must—

content.p: send notice of the change to the Secretary of State, and
publish the notice in the area of the CCA in such manner as the CCA considers appropriate, and
publish the notice in such other manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

intro.p: Where this subsection applies—

content.p: a reference in any enactment (whenever passed or made) to the mayor for the area of the CCA is, unless the context otherwise requires, to be read as a reference to the alternative title by which the mayor is to be known, and
references to mayor, mayoral (except in the expression “mayoral CCA”) and deputy mayor are to be construed accordingly.

A change of title under this section does not affect the rights or obligations of any person, or render defective any legal proceedings; and any legal proceedings may be commenced or continued as if there had been no change of title.

Where a mayoral CCA to which section 39 applies does not pass a resolution as required by subsection (1) of that section, the authority is to be treated for the purposes of this section as if, at the meeting mentioned in that subsection, it had passed the resolution mentioned in section 39(1)(a) (providing that the mayor is to be known by the title of mayor).
In this section a reference to a member of a CCA does not include a non-constituent member or an associate member.

intro.p: In this section—

content.p: enactment has the same meaning as in section 39;

intro.p: qualifying election means an election for the return of the mayor, other than—

content.p: the first election for the return of the mayor, and
an election caused by a vacancy in the office of the mayor occurring before expiry of the mayor’s term of office.
