section.heading: Power to specify environmental outcomes

content.p: Regulations made by the Secretary of State under this Part (“EOR regulations”) may specify outcomes relating to environmental protection in the United Kingdom or a relevant offshore area that are to be “specified environmental outcomes” for the purposes of this Part.

intro.p: “Environmental protection” means—

content.p: protection of the natural environment, cultural heritage and the landscape from the effects of human activity;
protection of people from the effects of human activity on the natural environment, cultural heritage and the landscape;
maintenance, restoration or enhancement of the natural environment, cultural heritage or the landscape;
monitoring, assessing, considering, advising or reporting on anything in paragraphs (a) to (c).

intro.p: The “natural environment” means—

content.p: plants, wild animals and other living organisms,
their habitats,
land (except buildings or other structures), air and water,

wrapUp.p: and the natural systems, cycles and processes through which they interact.

content.p: “Cultural heritage” means any building, structure, other feature of the natural or built environment or site, which is of historic, architectural, archaeological or artistic interest.

Before making any EOR regulations which contain provision about what the specified environmental outcomes are to be, the Secretary of State must have regard to the current environmental improvement plan (within the meaning of Part 1 of the Environment Act 2021).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Power to require environmental outcomes reports

section.heading: Environmental outcomes reports for relevant consents and relevant plans

content.p: EOR regulations may make provision requiring an environmental outcomes report to be prepared in relation to a proposed relevant consent or a proposed relevant plan.

intro.p: Where an environmental outcomes report is required to be prepared in relation to a proposed relevant consent—

content.p: the proposed relevant consent may not be given, unless an environmental outcomes report has been prepared in relation to it, and
that report must be taken into account or given effect, in accordance with EOR regulations, in determining whether and on what terms the proposed consent is to be given.

intro.p: Where an environmental outcomes report is required to be prepared in relation to a proposed relevant plan—

content.p: no step may be taken which would have the effect of bringing the proposed relevant plan into effect, unless an environmental outcomes report has been prepared in relation to it, and
that report must be taken into account or given effect, in accordance with EOR regulations, in determining whether and on what terms the proposed relevant plan is to have effect.

intro.p: An “environmental outcomes report”, in relation to a proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant plan, means a written report which assesses—

content.p: the extent to which the proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant plan would, or is likely to, impact on the delivery of specified environmental outcomes,

intro.p: any steps that may be proposed for the purposes of—

content.p: increasing the extent to which a specified environmental outcome is delivered;
avoiding the effects of a specified environmental outcome not being delivered to any extent;
so far as the effects of a specified environmental outcome not being delivered to any extent cannot be avoided, mitigating those effects;
so far as the effects of a specified environmental outcome not being delivered to any extent cannot be avoided or mitigated, remedying those effects;

so far as the effects of a specified environmental outcome not being delivered to any extent cannot be avoided, mitigated or remedied, compensating for the specified environmental outcome not being delivered, and

intro.p: any proposals about how—

content.p: the impact of the proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant plan on the delivery of a specified environmental outcome, or
the taking of any proposed steps of the kind mentioned in paragraph (b),

intro.p: The reference in subsection (4)(b) to steps includes—

content.p: reasonable alternatives to the relevant consent, to the project to which the relevant consent relates or to any element of either, or (as the case may be)
reasonable alternatives to the relevant plan or any element of it.

intro.p: Subsection (2) does not apply in relation to a relevant consent where—

content.p: the requirement for the consent is imposed under subsection (4) of section 118, and
the consent is to be given or refused in an environmental outcomes report in accordance with provision under subsection (5) of that section.

intro.p: EOR regulations may include provision about or in connection with—

content.p: what is to be taken to constitute the giving of a relevant consent for the purposes of subsection (2);
the proposed relevant consents and proposed relevant plans for which an environmental outcomes report is, or may be, required;
in relation to proposed relevant consents and proposed relevant plans for which an environmental outcomes report may be required, the circumstances in which a report is required;

an environmental outcomes report not needing to assess the extent to which a proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant plan would, or is likely to, impact on the delivery of a specified environmental outcome, where an adequate assessment of the impact on delivery of the outcome has in effect already been, or is to be, carried out in a different environmental outcomes report;
what proposals an environmental outcomes report may or must deal with under subsection (4)(b) and (c);
how any of the assessments mentioned in subsection (4) are to be carried out;

the information to be included in, and the content and form of, an environmental outcomes report, including provision requiring, or permitting a public authority to require, a report to deal with matters in addition to those provided for in subsection (4);

how, and to what extent, environmental outcomes reports are to be taken into account or given effect by public authorities in considering, and making decisions in relation to, relevant consents or relevant plans;
the carrying out of any proposals assessed in an environmental outcomes report under subsection (4)(b) or (c).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Defining the consents and plans to which this Part applies

section.heading: Power to define “relevant consent” and “relevant plan” etc

content.p: EOR regulations may provide that a consent of a description specified in the regulations (a “category 1 consent”) is to be a “relevant consent” for the purposes of this Part in all cases.

EOR regulations may provide that a consent of a description specified in the regulations (a “category 2 consent”) is to be a “relevant consent” for the purposes of this Part only if certain criteria specified in EOR regulations are met.
EOR regulations may make provision about, or in connection with, how, when and by whom it is to be determined whether criteria are met, such that a category 2 consent is a relevant consent.
EOR regulations may impose a requirement for a consent in relation to a project, which is to be a category 1 consent or a category 2 consent.

EOR regulations may make provision about, or in connection with, how a consent which is required under subsection (4) is to be given, including provision for it to be given (or refused) by an environmental outcomes report.

intro.p: “Relevant plan” means a plan or programme which—

content.p: relates, or may relate, to a project or to environmental protection in the United Kingdom or a relevant offshore area, and
is specified or described in EOR regulations for the purposes of this subsection.

References in this Part to a proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant plan include references to a proposed variation or modification of, or revision to, a relevant consent or relevant plan (however described).

“Consent” means any consent, approval, permission, authorisation, confirmation or decision (however described, given or made) that is required, or otherwise provided for, by or under any enactment in relation to a project.

intro.p: “Project” means a project in the United Kingdom or a relevant offshore area involving—

content.p: construction, engineering, demolition, dismantling or decommissioning,
the installation, depositing or removal of any thing,
the exploitation of natural resources by any means,
a change in the use of land, a building or other structure, or
any other activity capable of affecting the natural environment, cultural heritage or landscape.

section.heading: Assessing and monitoring impact on outcomes etc

content.p: EOR regulations may make provision about, or in connection with, how the extent to which a relevant consent or relevant plan actually affects the delivery of a specified environmental outcome is to be assessed or monitored.

EOR regulations may make provision about, or in connection with, how the carrying out of any proposals assessed in an environmental outcomes report under section 119(4)(b) or (c), or requirements under subsection (3), is to be assessed or monitored.

intro.p: EOR regulations may make provision requiring action to be taken, if an assessment or monitoring under subsection (1) or (2) determines that is appropriate for the purposes of—

content.p: increasing the extent to which a specified environmental outcome is delivered,
mitigating or remedying the effects of a specified environmental outcome not being delivered to any extent, or
compensating for a specified environmental outcome not being delivered to any extent.

section.heading: Safeguards: non-regression, international obligations and public engagement

content.p: The Secretary of State may make EOR regulations only if satisfied that making the regulations will not result in environmental law providing an overall level of environmental protection that is less than that provided by environmental law at the time this Act is passed.

EOR regulations may not contain provision that is inconsistent with the implementation of the international obligations of the United Kingdom relating to the assessment of the environmental impact of relevant plans and relevant consents.

In exercising functions under this Part, the Secretary of State must seek to ensure that (so far as would not otherwise be the case) arrangements will exist under which the public will be informed of any proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant plan in sufficient detail, and at a sufficiently early stage, to enable adequate public engagement to take place.

intro.p: In this section—

content.p: adequate public engagement means such engagement with the public, in relation to a proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant plan, as the Secretary of State considers appropriate;
environmental law means environmental law (within the meaning of Part 1 of the Environment Act 2021), whether or not the environmental law is in force.

section.heading: Requirements to consult devolved administrations

content.p: The Secretary of State may only make EOR regulations which contain provision within Scottish devolved competence after consulting the Scottish Ministers.

intro.p: Provision is “within Scottish devolved competence” where—

content.p: if the provision were included in an Act of the Scottish Parliament, it would be within the legislative competence of that Parliament,
the provision could be made by the Scottish Ministers, or

intro.p: the provision confers a function on, or modifies or removes a function of—

content.p: the Scottish Ministers, or

a person who exercises a function of a public nature which is exercisable in or as regards Scotland and the exercise of which would be within devolved competence (within the meaning of section 54 of the Scotland Act 1998).
The Secretary of State may only make EOR regulations which contain provision within Welsh devolved competence after consulting the Welsh Ministers.

intro.p: Provision is “within Welsh devolved competence” where—

content.p: if the provision were included in an Act of Senedd Cymru, it would be within the legislative competence of the Senedd (including any provision that could be made only with the consent of a Minister of the Crown),
the provision could be made by the Welsh Ministers, or

intro.p: the provision confers a function on, or modifies or removes a function of—

content.p: the Welsh Ministers,
a devolved Welsh authority within the meaning of the Government of Wales Act 2006 (see section 157A of that Act), or

a person who exercises a function of a public nature which is exercisable in or as regards Wales and could be conferred by provision falling within the legislative competence of Senedd Cymru (see section 108A of that Act).
The Secretary of State may only make EOR regulations which contain provision within Northern Ireland devolved competence after consulting a Northern Ireland department.

intro.p: Provision is within “Northern Ireland devolved competence” where—
the provision—

content.p: would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly, if contained in an Act of that Assembly, and
would not, if contained in a Bill for an Act of the Northern Ireland Assembly, result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State,
the provision could be made by a Northern Ireland department, or

intro.p: the provision confers a function on, or modifies or removes a function of—

content.p: a Northern Ireland department, or
a person who exercises a function of a public nature which is exercisable in or as regards Northern Ireland and could be conferred by provision falling within paragraph (a).
In this section “Minister of the Crown” has the same meaning as in the Ministers of the Crown Act 1975.

section.heading: Exemptions for national defence and civil emergency etc

content.p: The Secretary of State may direct that no environmental outcomes report is required to be prepared in relation to a proposed relevant consent which is solely for the purposes of national defence or preventing or responding to civil emergency.
EOR regulations may provide for further circumstances in which the Secretary of State is to be able to direct that no environmental outcomes report is required to be prepared.

A direction under this section may provide that provision in EOR regulations specified in the direction applies (subject to any modifications specified in the direction), despite the fact that no environmental outcomes report is required to be prepared.
The Secretary of State may modify or revoke a direction under this section.

section.heading: Enforcement

content.p: EOR regulations may make provision about, or in connection with, the enforcement of requirements imposed by or under this Part.

intro.p: EOR Regulations under this section may, in particular, include provision—

content.p: creating a criminal offence (but may not create a criminal offence punishable with imprisonment);
conferring a power on any court or tribunal;
for the imposition of civil sanctions and appeals against such sanctions;
conferring a power of entry (whether or not on the authority of a warrant);
conferring a power of inspection, search, seizure or detention (whether or not on the authority of a warrant);
authorising, or making provision for the authorisation of, the use of reasonable force in connection with a power mentioned in paragraph (d) or (e);
applying, or corresponding to, any provision, made by or under any enactment, relating to enforcement in connection with a category 1 consent or a category 2 consent (with or without modifications).
EOR regulations under subsection (2)(c) may make provision for the imposition of civil sanctions whether or not the conduct in respect of which the sanction is imposed constitutes an offence.

In this section “civil sanction” means a sanction of a kind for which provision may be made under Part 3 of the Regulatory Enforcement and Sanctions Act 2008 (fixed monetary penalties, discretionary requirements, stop notices, enforcement undertakings).

section.heading: Reporting

content.p: EOR regulations may make provision requiring a public authority to report on, or provide information in relation to, the delivery of specified environmental outcomes.

intro.p: EOR regulations may, in particular, include provision about or in connection with—

content.p: the information to be included in, and the content and form of, a report required under subsection (1);
the content and form of information required to be provided under subsection (1);
when, or the circumstances in which, the information or report must be provided;
the publication of the information or report;
who the information or report is to be provided to;
a report being combined with another document which is to be prepared under any enactment.

section.heading: Public consultation etc

intro.p: The Secretary of State must consult the public before making EOR regulations which contain provision—

content.p: under section 118(1) (specified environmental outcomes);
amending, repealing or revoking existing environmental assessment legislation.

intro.p: The Secretary of State must consult such persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate—
before making EOR regulations which contain provision under—

content.p: section 120(1) to (6) (consents and plans subject to this Part);
section 124(2) (power to provide for further exemptions by Secretary of State direction);
section 125 (enforcement).
section 129 (interaction with existing environmental assessment legislation and the Habitats Regulations);

intro.p: before issuing, modifying or withdrawing any guidance under section 126, which relates to—

content.p: how the likely impact of a proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant plan on the delivery of a specified environmental outcome should be assessed, or
how the extent to which a relevant consent or relevant plan actually affects the delivery of a specified environmental outcome should be assessed or monitored.
EOR regulations may require a public authority to respond, or to respond in a particular way or by a particular time, to a consultation under subsection (1) or (2).
The requirements to consult in subsections (1) and (2) may be met by consultation carried out before the subsection concerned comes into force.

section.heading: Guidance

content.p: A public authority carrying out a function under this Part, or existing environmental assessment legislation, must have regard to any guidance issued by the Secretary of State in relation to the function.

EOR regulations may require any person carrying out a function under EOR regulations to have regard to guidance issued by the Secretary of State in relation to the function, failing which the function is not to be regarded as having been validly carried out.

section.heading: Interaction with existing environmental assessment legislation and the Habitats Regulations

content.p: EOR regulations may make provision about, or in connection with, the interaction of this Part with existing environmental assessment legislation or the Habitats Regulations.

intro.p: EOR regulations under this section may, in particular, include provision—

content.p: treating anything done, or omitted to be done, in relation to an environmental outcomes report as satisfying or failing to satisfy a requirement under existing environmental assessment legislation or the Habitats Regulations;

treating anything done, or omitted to be done, under existing environmental assessment legislation or the Habitats Regulations as satisfying or failing to satisfy a requirement imposed by or under this Part;
about the co-ordination of things done under this Part and things done under existing environmental assessment legislation or the Habitats Regulations;

disapplying or otherwise modifying any provision of existing environmental assessment legislation or the Habitats Regulations where preparation of an environmental outcomes report is required under this Part;

disapplying or otherwise modifying any provision of this Part or EOR regulations where something is done, or required to be done, under existing environmental assessment legislation or the Habitats Regulations.
EOR regulations under this section may amend, repeal or revoke existing environmental assessment legislation.

intro.p: In this section “the Habitats Regulations” means—

content.p: regulation 5 of the Offshore Petroleum Activities (Conservation of Habitats) Regulations 2001 (S.I. 2001/1754);
regulation 24 and Part 6 of the Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations 2017 (S.I. 2017/1012);
regulations 27 to 37 of the Conservation of Offshore Marine Habitats and Species Regulations 2017 (S.I. 2017/1013).

section.heading: Consequential repeal of power to make provision for environmental assessment

content.p: TCPA 1990 is amended as follows.
Omit section 71A (assessment of environmental effects).
In section 293A (urgent Crown development: application), in subsection (4), omit paragraph (a).

section.heading: EOR regulations: further provision

intro.p: EOR regulations may make provision about or in connection with—

content.p: the procedure to be followed in relation to anything done under this Part, including the time by which anything must be done;
who is to prepare an environmental outcomes report, including provision permitting a public authority to determine who is to do so or the qualifications or experience a person must have to do so;
requiring a public authority to assist with any assessment or monitoring under this Part;
the publication of, and consultation and public engagement in connection with, environmental outcomes reports and other relevant documents;
the information to be included in, and the content and form of, any relevant document;
the persons to whom an environmental outcomes report or other relevant document is to be given, and how it is to be given;
the collection or provision of information in connection with this Part;

the rejection of a relevant document, or information provided in connection with this Part, if it is not provided in accordance with Chapter 1 of Part 3 (planning data), including provision requiring a document or information to be rejected;

how, and to what extent, any failure to comply with a requirement imposed by or under this Part is to be taken into account by public authorities in considering, and making decisions in relation to, relevant consents or relevant plans;
appeals against, or reviews of, decisions of a public authority about matters for, or in respect of, which provision is made by EOR regulations or existing environmental assessment legislation.

intro.p: EOR regulations may—

content.p: provide for the charging of fees or other charges;
confer a function, including a function involving the exercise of a discretion, on any person;
make consequential, supplementary or incidental provision under section 192(1)(c) which amends, repeals or revokes any legislation (whenever passed or made).

intro.p: In subsection (2)(c) “legislation” means any provision made by or under—

content.p: an Act,
an Act or Measure of Senedd Cymru,
an Act of the Scottish Parliament,
Northern Ireland legislation, or
retained direct EU legislation.

section.heading: Interpretation of Part 5

intro.p: “Existing environmental assessment legislation” means—

content.p: Schedule 3 to the Harbours Act 1964 (procedure for making harbour revision and empowerment orders) so far as relating to environmental impact assessments;
Part 5A of the Highways Act 1980 (environmental impact assessments);
sections 13A to 13D of the Transport and Works Act 1992 (environmental impact assessments);
the Offshore Petroleum Production and Pipe-lines (Assessment of Environmental Effects) Regulations 1999 (S.I. 1999/360);
the Public Gas Transporter Pipe-line Works (Environmental Impact Assessment) Regulations 1999 (S.I. 1999/1672);
the Environmental Impact Assessment (Land Drainage Improvement Works) Regulations 1999 (S.I. 1999/1783);
the Environmental Impact Assessment (Forestry) (England and Wales) Regulations 1999 (S.I. 1999/2228);
the Nuclear Reactors (Environmental Impact Assessment for Decommissioning) Regulations 1999 (S.I. 1999/2892);
the Pipe-line Works (Environmental Impact Assessment) Regulations 2000 (S.I. 2000/1928);
the Water Resources (Environmental Impact Assessment) (England and Wales) Regulations 2003 (S.I. 2003/164);
the Environmental Assessment of Plans and Programmes Regulations 2004 (S.I. 2004/1633);
the Transport and Works (Applications and Objections Procedure)(England and Wales) Rules 2006 (S.I. 2006/1466) so far as dealing with environmental matters;
the Environmental Impact Assessment (Agriculture) (England) (No. 2) Regulations 2006 (S.I. 2006/2522);
the Marine Works (Environmental Impact Assessment) Regulations 2007 (S.I. 2007/1518);
the Town and Country Planning (Environmental Impact Assessment) Regulations 2017 (S.I. 2017/571);
the Infrastructure Planning (Environmental Impact Assessment) Regulations 2017 (S.I. 2017/572);
the Electricity Works (Environmental Impact Assessment) (England and Wales) Regulations 2017 (S.I. 2017/580);
the Offshore Oil and Gas Exploration, Production, Unloading and Storage (Environmental Impact Assessment) Regulations 2020 (S.I. 2020/1497).

intro.p: In this Part—

content.p: category 1 consent and “category 2 consent” have the meaning given by section 120(1) and (2);
cultural heritage section 118(4);
environmental outcomes report has the meaning given by section 117(4);
environmental protection has the meaning given by section 118(2);
EOR regulations has the meaning given by section 118(1);
existing environmental assessment legislation has the meaning given by subsection (1);
natural environment has the meaning given by section 118(3);
project has the meaning given by section 120(9);
proposed, in relation to a relevant consent or relevant plan, is to be construed in accordance with section 120(7);

intro.p: public authority means—

content.p: any person with functions under, or functions in respect of which provision is made by, existing environmental assessment legislation when this Act is passed;
any public authority within the meaning of section 6 of the Human Rights Act 1998, other than a court or tribunal;
relevant consent has the meaning given by section 120;
relevant document means a document or information for, or in respect of, which provision is made by EOR regulations or existing environmental assessment legislation;

intro.p: relevant offshore area means any area in—

content.p: the territorial sea adjacent to the United Kingdom,
any area designated by Order in Council under section 1(7) of the Continental Shelf Act 1964, or
any area designated by Order in Council under section 41(3) of the Marine and Coastal Access Act 2009;
relevant plan has the meaning given by section 120(6);
specified environmental outcome has the meaning given by section 116(1).
